text: I just can't get enough of their sandwiches! Best Cuban sandwich I've ever had. Drool. And I love the Scottwich and reuben.

I am a native New Yorker, from Brooklyn, I know Deli.. Scott's USED to be my go to place, sadly...no more. 
The greeting was warm and friendly as usual, but.. the place was empty .. it was a Friday about 3:30 pm..the only thing there.. was the roach that was on our table...
The waiter was less than interested in killing it, we moved to another table having already ordered. I would have left, but my octogenarian parents wanted to stay.. the sandwiches, that should have been hot, were look warm if that, they were not as flavorful as they had been, the fries were good,but we had to wait too long for the frier oil to heat up. 
The waiter eventually killed the roach on the other table, but only after I got up to go tell the man at the front counter. Then no one washed the table!! GROSS!! 
I would (as a customer service professional) have offered something for the unpleasant experience, even if it was only a complimentary round of soda! But not even an apology was offered. 
Sorry Scott's, you lost this generation...

I'm surprised how well this deli is reviewed... I've given it about 5 chances now.  It always looks promising, and is right next door to the Jewish bakery which I love.  Unfortunately, I've been pretty let down each time I've tried to grab some good food from Scott's.

The service is terrible, at least for take-out.  They take their time and acknowledge you if they feel like it.  I don't know about dine-in service, but you can tell having a smile would get a waitress fired.

As for the food... potato knishs looked outstanding, tasted like something you could buy frozen.  Bagels were okay but I had the bar raised.  Scallion cream cheese left a lot to be desired, which is sad because I consider a good everything bagel with scallion cream cheese to be the ultimate new york breakfast treat (after a good egg sandwich, of course).  Damn, the egg sandwich was awful that one time... did they get their bacon from Wendy's?

Still looking for a good NY deli, so feel free to pass one on!  Wish it could have been Scott's.
Everything I have tried is great. Piled high with deli meat and homemade potato fries. My favorite is the Ross

I love family owned restaurants and will gladly try any place that isn't a franchise.  I was very surprised to go in on a Saturday morning and the place was bustling with activity and lots of diners, all of whom looked to be regulars and quite happy with their morning blintz or eggs.  I ordered a pumperdine bagel with lox, cream cheese and onions and it was top notch and piled high with lox.  Delicious.  Love the deli pickles, very authentic, not your normal over vinegared store brand.  

I would love to go back soon, after seeing their list of smoked fish...I love a good deli with fish choices and I can't wait to also try a corned beef sandwich.
The Lox platter is amazing! Great Jewish Deli. Has a bit of an old school feel to it.

Any restaurant that proudly displays 'American Fries' and 'All-American Toast' as a substitution for 'French Fries' and 'French Toast' are just mindless and a bit moronic. I asked our server about what I perceived as a type-o. She grinned her best 3 tooth grin and kindly answered  "It's cause we don't like those French for not supporting us in Iraq." Uh. Ok.  

If you want a good meal, and not feel like your IQ dropped 15 points for reading the menu, I suggest not going to Scott's Generations.

I love Scott's. Pure and simple. This place is a gem from top to bottom. I've been coming here for over a year and food and service is always fast, friendly, and delish. 

The bagels are awesome- try the egg bagel. I used to come in every Thursday and eat a bagel, drink tons of coffee, and read the New Times. The waitresses were always very sweet to me and I felt right at home. I also love how they don't scrimp on the cream cheese.

The fiance and I usually have breakfast here and could easily share a plate because it is SO MUCH FOOD! The sandwiches look amazing (again... SO MUCH FOOD!) and the deserts look fantastic. 

Try the latkes and the breakfast sandwich with challa bread. It'll make you wanna holla! 

...See what I did there?

When I have a serious craving for pastrami, these guys are my go to. The menu is extensive, the service is always good and the food is outstanding. They also have some of the best corned beef hash I've ever had. I recommend them to all my friends whenever I can.

Let's talk about Jewish delis.

This is Phoenix, not Detroit or Boston or New York or Los Angeles, but hot damn, the food here definitely could be. Coming from Detroit, I have been searching for a proper bagel, a properly smoked salmon, a proper Reuben, a properly seeded rye, a proper YOU NAME IT, and Scott's has served. Don't walk in here expecting a fancy dining experience; it's not that kind of place. It features quality, monster portions and incredibly friendly staff. 

Every restaurant is going to have have a particular specialty. For Scott's, go in and ask them what that specialty is. If you ask for mostacholi at a deli, there's a good chance it might let you down. But if you ask for kugel or corned beef or matzoh ball soup, this is your jam. For me, it's a taste of home. 

The three best parts of my trip: Crunchy new-dill pickles, Dr. Browns pop, and perfectly seasoned cow tongue (yum!). My friend got the Black Forest (which is smoked turkey and corned beef with actual carmelized onions on pumpernickel) and I got the Scott's Ruben-Ruben; both were SUPERB and large enough for us to take home 3/4's of them. We could not stop effusing or closing our eyes in happiness. The prices are standard; the options are endless; the service is fast, friendly, and knowledgeable. Treat yourself. You won't be disappointed.
Best Deli and awesome people! Scott's Generation's is a landmark! I can't wait to have a real New York Ruben!

Heard good things about this place and it's close to home so we thought, "Let's try it". I'll start with the good first: The pancakes were very good. Now for the rest...I ordered the eggs benedict and when it came the bread it was on was the rubberiest, toughest bread I've ever tried to chew, there was barely any hollandaise sauce and the cheese was a square of cheap American cheese. The deal-breaker though was the eggs which were cooked until the yolk was as solid as any hard-boiled egg. I took a couple of bites and notified my waitress of how poorly done the dish was. She offered to send it back to be re-done but I declined. I never send food back, especially eggs! This was an $11 dish and they couldn't even poach a damn egg?! The waitress said she notified the manager but by the time the bill came no manager had come out to apologize or offer to take off that item from the bill. When I paid I informed the waitress that if that was how Scott's treated it's customers I would never be back. And I won't. Mediocre food was bad enough. Rude, uncaring management means I will tell as many people as I can of my experience and never set foot in that place again. Hope the management think their $7 or $8 profit was worth that. 

The one star is for the pancakes.

I was really disappointed in the food here. We live close and like to support the restaurants by us so we decided to go for lunch. We ordered the Greek salad and a sandwich with fries. The salad was made with cheap iceberg lettuce and was soggy with dressing. I don't think it sat too long, I think that is just how the salad is. The sandwich looked good but tasted very mediocre. I'm sorry to say that I won't be back and had high hopes for this new restaurant in our hood. Possibly it's better for breakfast but I'm not willing to spend my money to find out.

Atmosphere is very clean service was really good very friendly I order steak and eggs the eggs were great the potatoes was good the steak was overcooked And dry.  Great selection on the menu many amazing things.

Worst lunch ever at Scott's Generations Restaurant on Glendale. 
There were six of us. Even though we had reservations which had been confirmed, the restaurant wasn't ready for us and we had a long wait before we were led to a back room and our orders taken. I ordered the French dip, and when it arrived the bottom of the bun was soggy to the point of falling apart, but the plate was dry. Hmmm. I tried all through the meal to get the waiter's, or someone's, anyone's, attention to no avail. The waiter never checked back with us to see if everything was ok (it wasn't) or if we needed anything else (I wanted more water and a new sandwich), but we were ignored until the waiter decided to present the checks. Then it was far too late to order a replacement French dip. I was very hungry and had tried to nibble at the top of the bun; there was no question of dipping it into the au jus as the bottom of the bun was already soaked with something I didn't want to think about. as the bottom of the plate was dry, I still wonder where the sandwich had been before it was served to me.

We came here for breakfast for lunch. I am told my my lunch-going partner that the corned beef hash was very good (specifically better than Chompie's). The everything bialy and onion bagels we had were pretty good. The bagel was not as dense as a typical bagel. The home fries were strangely bland with some heat. The pricing was reasonable for breakfast. 
I will probably come back here to try other things like the cheese blitzes.
One of the best deli's in Phoenix. Great food all around. Everyone is so nice and friendly, definitely worth a visit!

To be honest, the only time I go to a deli is when I have a cold and need chicken soup. So today, I was feeling horrible. I did a quick search and found this place. It was 25 minutes away, but good soup is worth the drive.

It was serviceable. 

I went with the mish mosh since I usually get a kreplach/matzo ball combo. What got was a funny tasting broth (sweet onions?), two hard matzo balls, and no kreplach. The veggies/noodles/rice/chicken were good so it wasn't a complete disappointment.

Service was kind of slow, but friendly. 

It wasn't worth my lunch hour.

I had the pleasure of eating lunch here today and it did not disappoint! 

We split "The New Yorker", a delicious and very large corned beef and pastrami sandwich. The meat melted in your mouth and had the perfect amount of flavor between the meat, Russian dressing and creamy cole slaw. 

The french fries weren't the best and the sandwich is rather pricey but overall I give this place four stars. I am looking forward to a return trip very soon!

Let me explain the 1 star ....

I've been to Scott's a few times before ... LOVED IT! I've sat outside, ordered to go but never have I sat inside until last week.

Was visiting with friends and we got a booth, placed our orders ... started to chit-chat and out of the corner of my eye, I see something on the wall. No! Couldn't be! Why yes, it was your friendly neighborhood roach! And he brought a friend! We gals stopped talking midstream, looking around to see if anyone else saw what we did. Why yes!! our server saw the two unwelcome guests as she was standing at the food delivery window. Guess what she did??! Nothing. Until we pointed them out and rapidly moved to another table.

Honestly, we all were wigged out. Talk about an appetite lost! Too bad. I had totally enjoyed Scott's up until then. 

Most likely will not be back.

Came for the first time seen from Check Please, Arizona. Service here is strange because I'm not used to seating myself so I asked the cashier for food and placed it. Sat down and waited for a while, my dad got his order real quick and my took a while from a minor miscommunication. All in all my dads Reuben-Reuben,(and yes I said that right) it's all the Reuben you could ever want. Pretty relaxed place. 5 stars for charisma.

Heard about this place, ran in to check it out and see what it's all about. 
Ran into a former classmate of mine from back in culinary school. Small world...

I sat myself for lunch, was immediately greeted and had my drink order taken. 
I had the hot pastrami on pumpernickel. It came with 2 homemade pickles cut in half and a small portion of coleslaw. Sandwich with side was $12. Not too bad considering it had probably 10oz of meat on it. 
Very good sandwich, and it rivaled Chompies. 
I look forward to eating their more often.. maybe for breakfast.. if I get  up that early..
They have the best corn beef in Phoenix.  I haven't found a place like Scott's anywhere in Phoenix or the surrounding cities.

I stopped by here on a whim for lunch and decided to take a chance on a corned beef, pastrami, and tongue sandwich on rye. The tongue was surprisingly fresh-tasting and tongue-y. The pastrami was without gristle. And the corned beef was as one may expect for a decent corned beef. A perfect compliment to the sandwich.

I'm sure that the less perhaps "exotic" combinations are equally as delicious, though.

Solid place, I believe. I'll be back again.

My car is currently being worked on and I was craving a real breakfast but couldn't leave the house. I thought I was completely out of luck until I found out this place delivers to my area. I ordered breakfast skillets for myself and my husband and we were both impressed by the quality and the amount of food! We both only ate half so even though it was a bit expensive, we get a whole other meal out of it so I was happy. Plus there is no delivery fee, but you have to get a minimum $20 order (not hard to do if feeding 2 people). Overall I was very impressed and delivery was about 30 minutes, like they said. I will definitely order from here again.

I don't really know where to start with Scott's Generation. I come from the Northeast... when it comes to authentic Jewish delis, it's the land of plenty. In Arizona, I'm lucky to find a deli that even has actually edible corned beef on rye. Scott's Generation offers very good pseudo-Jewish food, but for being "unofficial" in my mind, it's pretty good.

Scott's has all the staples of an East Coast Jewish deli:

1. Dr. Browns soda
2. Matzaball Soup
3. A "special" (cole slaw and russian dressing on X sandwich)
4. Wise chips

Unfortunately when going to Scott's, I felt like the only Jew in a few mile radius. This was highlighted even more when I asked for Challah french toast. The waitress responded with just "huh?"... As I looked down on the menu, I realized their challah french toast is actually "Kelly's American Toast" with challah french toast written in small font underneath. Looking further on the menu, I was happy to see that they have an option to get kreplach in your soup... but upon further inspection, next to kreplach it says "wonton" in parentheses...

*rustling sound*

That sound you just heard (read) was my great grandparents rolling over in their graves. That's like going to an Italian restaurant in Israel, ordering spaghetti and marinara, and in parentheses seeing "egg noodles and ketchup" (at least to me).

Anyway... food wise, I give Scott's Generation a solid 3.5 stars. The service was also a solid 3.5. I give Scott's a 2 on the Jewish deli scale. In the end, Scott's gets an A-OK 3 stars, and I plan to go back one day.

I don't know if it's a childhood thing but Scott's Matzo Ball soup is THE only thing that help with my ailments. Big dense matzo balls like my great aunt Betty would make. The Reuben isn't to be forgotten either. A traditional New York deli is hard to find in Phoenix.

Been a few times checking out various items. The deli meat sandwiches are great and served in huge portions ala Carnegie Deli in NY.  The place feels like it needs a makeover in physical atmosphere and attitude of the counter staff. Today I had the Kreplach Soup which aside from the unappetizing greenish color had way too much salt in it and I'm not salt phobic or anything. Is that much salt really necessary? My table server was excellent. Mixed feelings.

Had lunch here on a recent Saturday.  The pastrami was ok, but it was tough and sliced too thickly.  Coleslaw is good, and the pickles were just starting to get sour.

The fries were great, but not enough to make up for lackluster pastrami.

I would go back, but with low expectations.

Favorite Jewish deli, hands down. Have been here MANY times. Of course, the food is really greasy, but there IS a dance studio right next door...

The good: great food. Some of it can be a little 'unexpected', and may not taste as you have tried before, but I would say it's still good. My favorite is The Scottwich. It's pretty big and LOADED with meat, which I love. If I'm going to have something, I want a lot of it, not just a little sampler. The breakfast here is pretty good, as well. Now, my favorite part: the cheesecake. Holyyyyyy....yes, it is amazing. I've had a lot of cheese cake - though I would not consider myself a connoisseur - and, in my opinion, Generations' cheesecake is pretty phenomenal. 

I recommend sitting outside - the inside feels a little shabby, and a little stuffy. Surprisingly, I haven't come across any flies yet while eating outside. Oh - and you can smoke outside, which is just fantastic for smokers. For those who don't smoke, fortunately, there are a lot of tables outside, so you can sit far away from me. 

The bad: some of the employees come across as, oh, I don't know..bitter? The average waitress there is at retirement age, which is fine, and that can be really nice: "what would ya like sweetie?". But the one of the waitresses at Generations doesn't seem too happy to be there - and she shows it.  That waitress, well,  you can definitely tell when she is having a bad day. I once asked for a little cup of powdered sugar and she gave me the evil eyes!! I couldn't believe it! And neither could my friends and family! But there have been times when she has been very sweet. Though you're walking on eggshells with her. If you get her, be careful not to ask for anything extra. The other employees, I'm not sure about, because we've only really gotten 'her', but I know there is a younger waitress who happens to be very nice and professional. 

Anyways, over all, Generations is an authentic deli, with great food (and cheesecake). And if you feel as bloated as I do after eating there, waddle on over to the dance studio next door and sign up for a Zumba class - and say hi to me. We'll talk about their fabulous cheesecake while doing some cardio.

I'm in this neighborhood each month. Now, I'm kicking myself for not stopping at Scott's sooner. It's the real deal!
I had the New Yorker. Oh my! The rye bread was so good. Stacked high with both pastrami and corned beef. I can't wait to get back.

I live not far away, and regularly visit several of the other businesses in this strip mall, but had never tried Scott's until about a week ago.  We arrived mid-afternoon.  It was dark and dingy, and even though we're both almost Medicare age, we were the youngest people in the joint (including the staff).  Not that there's anything wrong with that, but it felt strange. The menus were filthy.  Service was adequate, but a bit slow.  

My partner had the corned beef hash breakfast, and had no complaints - there were fresh onions and peppers in the hash; the 3 eggs on top were perfectly cooked, and the potatoes and toast were fine.  I tasted the hash, and liked it.  The portions were huge. 

I ordered the chopped liver.  I don't know much about chopped liver, except I've made my own a few times and eaten it once from a Philadelphia deli (the Philly stuff was incredibly good).  This was awful; just awful.  Since when is it sweet, with no hint of onion?  I must not be alone, because I heard a woman at the table near us tell the staff "you don't know how to cook liver."

I'd probably try Scott's again for breakfast, but PLEASE:  turn on some lights, wipe off the menus, dust the place up, sweep the floor.  If I'm going to pay above average prices for mediocre food, the place needs to be minimally clean and bright.

Disclaimer: my concerns come to the vegetarian dishes. I've eaten here twice both the veggie Ruben and the vegetarian sub. Just felt like an after thought. Been trying to stay vegetarian lately and it's been tough to find something halfway decent. Their other food looks good.
This place has an amazing Reuben sandwich! The place could be a little cleaner, but all in all a great place to get an awesome sandwich.

Service was great.  Our waitress stayed on top of our needs. My associate and I  work in a CPA firm down the street.  We decided to go to lunch here. The environment is nice - not outstanding but the place was clean. I ordered the Rueben which was fantastic it completely met my expectations.  My associate ordered the Juan's Join the Club.  He was underwhelmed. He told me the sandwich was dry and that he would have to take the half he did not eatit home and freshen it up.
I love this place. Sandwiches are huge, the bagels n' cream cheese are always fresh, and the servers are unique and accommodating. Every time I come here I feel like Norm from Cheers!

First time customer and will NEVER be back.

Over $12.00 for a veggie sandwich and fountain soda that was supposed to be served with a deli pickle and side of fresh fruit. The fruit 'cup' was literally 3 grapes and 2 pieces of cantaloupe stuffed into one of those tiny 2oz plastic dishes that should be used for ketchup to-go. My 'deli' pickle was 3 small, soggy, soft spears that were terrible and I swear had somehow gone bad (how can a pickle go bad, you say? I don't know either, but Scott's managed to do it.)

My sandwich was okay, but was on genaric wheat bread, loaded with raw red onion (I'm talking about nearly half an onion) a piece of lettuce and a slice of tomato. Their veggie cream cheese was the only saving grace to the sandwich, but was lumped on in the middle of the bread, so I had to dissect the sandwich to remove a lot of onion and spread the cream cheese around.

Besides the poor quality food, the service was terrible. I walked in and placed my order to go. I got out my card to pay, and the guy at the counter said I could wait until my food was ready. 7 minutes later, there were 3 other tables trying to pay for their meals at the only register in the place, so I had to wait longer. never mind the fact that (I actually think it was the owner?) interrupted the customer in front of me to talk to the guy at the register about his cell phone that was ringing... Seriously?!

Bottom line: get way better service, don't serve deli pickles if they're not, and if you're going to offer a veggie sandwich, give it just as much love and attention as you give the corned beef hash and liver you serve.
Bad food bad service greasy matzo ball soup. Skip this dump. I literally took one bite and left it was so bad. Went to subway next door instead

Had the Pastrami sandwich and it was satisfactory.  It was on the dry side.  It comes with fries and they were just fine.  Now, I did have the homemade brownies, and they were awesome!  Would order those to go:-)

We went to Scott's Generations on a sammich mission.  We want to find the best of the best sammiches, and we found some of them!

I ordered the "Mike's Jumbo Philly Cheesesteak" which was really delicious.  Great flavor in the meat, veggies, and bread.  My only problem was it wasn't so jumbo.  It was normal, but honestly, I don't know if I could have finished it if it was jumbo.  

The side of fries was pretty tasty, perfectly done crinkles, a great compliment to the sammich.  

I also tried my friend's "The James Cagney" (Brisket) and another friend's "Scott's Perfect Reuben-Reuben" (Which was half pastrami half corned beef).  

Both of those sammiches were also delicious.  Perfectly cooked meat, great bread, not much more you could ask for.

Out of all three of the sandwiches "The Scott's Perfect Reuben" was probably the best.  So if you are having a hard time choosing, go with the Reuben (half / half).

This place is a little pricy for a sandwich, but it is well worth it.  I will definitely be back again!

This reminded me of going to the deli in NYC.  The type of food, the bagels, the excellent mustard, the black & white cookies, ... and oh, the knish!  I went during a slow time - so I had a few minutes to ask about their sandwiches and recommendations without slowing down everyone else.  I enjoyed the experience - the service, the food, the selection.  I will definitely be back.

The food is pretty good, BUT

1. it is inconsistent.  One day I'll get lots of cream cheese on my bagel and another day they'll skimp out on it and leave lots of dry parts.  I paid $5 for a pint of matzo ball soup and got one tiny (and very dense) matzo ball--felt a little ripped off. There should be standard portions I think.

2. I think I was over charged my first time there.  My bill came to $10 but according to the menu my bagel was 3.20 and the soup was $4.95.  Is the tax rate 20% now? The amount is so small that I didn't make an issue of it, but I read another review complaining of the same thing so I think it's worth mentioning. 

I'll still go back for bagels because they are way better than Einsteins, especially the cream cheese, but I'll be sure to check any to-go orders for skimpy portions before leaving next time, and check my bill carefully before paying.

Okay I've been here before and had the hungery man breakfast when I got my meal I was told that there was no more sausage, this would have been nice to know this when I ordered it and who runs out of sausage at a deli. The portions were very small for 10 bucks and the restroom was not clean at all....not too happy right now and still hungery....gerrrr

I love the food here. Real NY style over stuffed (boars head cold cuts)sandwiches. I love the bagels.  The Matzoh Ball soup rocks too...I would give this place 4 stars but every time I come in the owner/management gives a really crappy vibe..I know I usually come in late afternoon and they are quiet,  they just had a busy breakfast/lunch so its all good, maybe they are winding down from a tough morning....Having said that, Im NOT looking for any special attention because Ive been going there on and off for 5 years. But seriously? Act like you give a hoot (hoot is code for $%*)...I would be there all the time if they acted a little gracious and chill...

I've been coming to Scott's since I was a kid. Great bagel breakfast sandwiches with 2 eggs cooked to order, a bagel of choice, meat of your choice and cheese of your choice for around $5. Their pastrami is also delicious.  Try their Scottwich!

Arrived at this place for the first time.  Was told to go "sit" at a booth; that menus were on the table.

Searched for a clean table even though the restaurant was nearly empty and had multiple waiters sitting around including the person at the register.

Other than my waitperson, the rest of staff looked at me as if I were from Mars, not evening smiling in my direction.

If your looking for food, go. If your looking for good service, go somewhere else.

We stopped eating breakfast there long ago due to always getting our order incorrect. Eggs always burnt, nothing tasting good. Today we stopped for bagels and cookies to go. The cookies were so rock hard and stale I can't believe they would even sell them. The rainbow cookies you could not even bite. They resembled a tiny brick. This place gets worse and worse.

Not happy with my service, hair found in wife's sandwich, and then during another visit was left hanging waiting for the manager to get off the phone he was conducting a phone interview, and no waitress even looked to take care of us at the deli counter. Will not visit or spend my hard earned money at Scott's !

The James Cagney sandwich is hands down the best sandwich I've ever had. Their new location is in a great spot and it's closer to my office! Great service from all of the staff too. I recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for some delicious grub. Order the James Cagney and you won't be disappointed.

Been here enough including several times since I started reviewing on yelp but have held back...today, I'm busting it out.

I have a lifetime of eating in various Jewish deli's in Chicago, Florida and Arizona and Scott's is typical, not exceptional but certainly a restaurant where food is decent, portions are excessive and pricing is never a bargain.

So I have no particular gripes and I would recommend the place to others who are looking for good chicken noodle/matzah ball soup or a massive corned beef or pastrami sandwich. For this you cannot go wrong here.

Scott's has become one of the go-to places on our list of Sunday breakfast spots. The food is great, the service is good, and the brownies are to die for. 

You won't find anything fancy here- the food is simple, wholesome and tasty. The french toast is perfect. I was informed by one of our breakfast crew that the chorizo is way too spicy, but I don't know why you'd order chorizo in a Jewish deli when there are so many other good things on the menu. 

On my last visit, I had a veggie omelet. That thing was as big as my head, served with yummy potatoes, and provided two tasty breakfasts. Whatever Scott's lacks in style, they make up for in cheese. Holy hell, was there cheese. Not a bad thing, just a little overwhelming. 

The brownies are to die for. I haven't tasted a better brownie since...well, I just can't remember. Scott's brownies are cakey, perfectly moist, slathered in a not-too-sweet frosting, and they're HUGE. 

Give Scott's a try. The menu is large enough that there really is something for everyone. I doubt you'll be disappointed.
Great food and wow what a menu....you could eat here everyday and not have to have the same thing twice.

We had breakfast here today and it was very good.  We had the Lox and bagel plate which had a generous portion of Nova Lox and plenty of condiments.  we also had the Greek Omelet which was very tasty and had a nice proprotion of veggies to eggs.

Service is attentive and friendly - a nice find

New location same great taste!  I have been going to Scotts for 10 plus years and every time it's a great experience.  The staff is always friendly and the food is unbelievable.  The new location is beautiful with a very upbeat vibe.  If in the area I would highly recommend you stop to check it out.

Scotts is what you expect when you say Jewish Deli.  The corned beef hash is crispy on the outside, with green peppers and onions mixed in.  All of the portions are large to say the least.  The first time we went was for breakfast, but after seeing a corned beef sandwich go by, I changed my order!  Bacon that tastes like bacon, eggs cooked the way you ask for them, and lots of personality in the staff and owner.  Jan is a hoot, and Scott is always behind the counter to add color.  Not fancy, and you will have to Fabreeze when you get home, but a great meal that a chain will never match.

I really enjoy this place- if you like bialy's like I do, they have the BEST bialy's in town in my opinion.  If you get an entree, be prepared to take some home, as their portions are enormous.

It's a typical New York family owned deli.  Sometimes one of the owners (I think he's the son of the owner) can be pretty moody and rude but if you can deal with that, it's worth it for the food.  I go back here all the time when I'm in the mood for a good bialy or breakfast.  Excellent cream cheeses too- my favorite is their veggie cream cheese.  They have lunch and dinner too.  Give it a shot!  I can't think of a better Jewish deli in town.

This place is on the list.

You know, that list you keep of places you plan on coming back to, again and again? It might be purely mental or physical, but when someone within earshot says "i'm in the mood for a Reuben" that list springs into action.

Scott's Generations is at the top of that list, for sure.

I've never ever had sandwiches, nay sammiches, quite like this. But, being from California I've never had the pleasure of an authentic Jewish Delicatessen either. Our table ordered a half-and-half Reuben, a jumbo philly cheese steak, and my order, the James Cagney: a beef brisket sammich on an onion roll with coleslaw and some amazing chunky fries on the side.

My mouth is watering purely from the memory... My friends and I each kept half of our respective orders, but cut the other halves in two so that everyone could get a taste of everything. The cheese steak wasn't bad, but I've had better. My brisket was GLORIOUS, and I savored every bite. I even got up to grab some mustard for accompaniment but it went unused since it was so perfect and juicy. I have to say though, that the quarter piece of the Reuben I tried was definitely my favorite thing on the table. AH! IT WAS SO GOOD!

Not only can Scott's build a perfect sammich, they back it up with stellar service and great attitudes. It was a little pricey, but I also felt that for the price you got a TON of food! I'll be back soon. and again. and again and again, with friends.

How have I not sang Scott's praises yet? Well, here I go! 

Do you want a place for a good, solid, stick to your ribs breakfast without being too frou frou? Scott's is the joint! It's a Jewish deli in the middle of my neighborhood! I was so surprised that I hadn't noticed it before! Chrissy P invited me to join her for breakfast one morning and I was just blown away! On my first visit, I had the eggs Benedict. My only complaint was that my eggs were a tad overcooked, (not runny) and I wished for more hollandaise sauce. 

For my second visit, I brought my little sis and her BFF and we chowed! I had the Hash Mash and we shared an order of the french toast. I don't know why I challenged myself to my own personal "how much breakfast can you stuff into your stomach" contest, but I think I won. Everything was so good! There was nothing to complain about. 

I wish I could go to Scott's every day for a hearty breakfast! The dishes are simple, the service is straight forward, and I have NEVER walked away hungry. I will return very, very soon!

Wow. They messed up the most basic stuff. Really horrible, all the way around.

Let's see-- asked for kreplach soup, which is not on the menu. They have matzo ball and they have mish mosh (noodles, matzo, kreplach). I asked for kreplach soup and they brought me one dumpling. So how many dumplings in the mish mosh? One, right? So if I want the kreplach soup, then I would expect 2 or 3 dumplings. Call me crazy!

The soup was also cold.

Chopped liver tasted like liver... "Livery". At better delis, the chopped liver is smooth and creamy-- slightly sweet. This was bitter and not smooth. Unpleasant. I think it was made from chickens who drank a lot of cheap booze and popped pills.

They served it with bagel chips... Which is great, except a few good sized bagel chips were cinnamon-raisin. You gotta be kidding me. With liver? Disgusting.

Meatloaf was a friggin' nightmare. Not sliced from a loaf, but a patty that was baked. Super well done, chewy crap. Served with a beef base gravy, and they used way too much beef base.

Carrots were overcooked; mashed potatoes were ordinary.

My bill was $43. With tip, $50. Service was polite, but a little slow.

I am so angry that I paid for this crap. This is the second worst meal I've ever paid for in my life. I'm 40.

Very, very bad restaurant. Ugh.

I've been going to Scotts Generations for 13 or 14 years now. The food is always consistently delicious! The prices are a bit higher than what I'd like to pay for breakfast/lunch, but considering the HUGE portions, it's totally worth it! If your bubbie used to make knishes, blintzes, or matza ball soup you can't stop daydreaming about, try this place out!

Way over priced for the menu.   Ordered "Anitas Smothered delight" ($14),  a chicken sandwich covered in sauteed mushrooms and onions.  Ordered to go.  When i got home and opened the box it was a chicken Cesar salad.   With only three tables seated, you would think they could get an order right.   Sorry,  off my list.

This place is okay.  My sandwich was huge, the corned beef and pastrami was very flavorful. The matzo ball soup was a huge disappointment..it was like malt-o-meal mashed in to a ball that had sat in a freezer and turned to a gelatinous blob, not good.  The potatos on the side were nothing special and there was no uniformity to how they were cooked. Service was ok.

Well this was my second time eating over at Scotts and I thought maybe a second try would have made it better...especially since I went to go buy a gift card for my boss who loves the place.

I ordered the Scottwich which is a huge sandwich piled high with pastrami, swiss cheese, grilled onions and generously served with side fries, pickles and coleslaw. My sandwich was simply Perfection! (about 13.50 after tax)

Unfortunately the service is not....hence the 3 stars.

When I called in Tony (The big guy in the front-I think thats his name) placed me on hold for 3 minutes, I thought they must have been really slammed, but when I went for pick up they were fairly busy but not packed. He had no patience and no sense of customer service whatsoever! I asked to purchase a gift card and he said they didn't have any, I then asked for a certificate of some sort and he said that he could make me one but threw a large fit because he had to... Then I proceeded to ask for a pound of cookies and he shouted "como chingas" which is not something very nice to say to a person (Those who are bilingual in Spanish know what im talking about). He became extremely stressed at having to write out a certificate and have phone calls and waitresses coming up to cash out the checks. He got even more upset and walked away! I apologized and said that I would just purchase one of the pre-packaged cookies that were on display... $50 dollars later I received my cookies, my to-go order and my $25 gift certificate. 

The food is awesome-definitely worth the price, but be prepared for the mediocre service!

Man I normally don't like Reuben sandwiches but this one was amazing bread was perfectly crisp not soggy the sauerkraut was just wrong enough to get the flavor but then it over power the beef the beef was super tender not over brine just very well bound sandwich and that it was piled high not too bad for 14 bucks server was great too pretty fast to getting things I'll top of getting drinks and making sure head refills the whole time egg burrito was mediocre though when I get that again also use the free dessert checking offer don't get that brownie cheesecake not good at all very dry more brownie flavor than anything definitely will go back for the Ruben

Ordered takeout for lunch at work.  Not a quick order place, as it took quite a while to get my food.  Definitely overpriced (for $12.50 your sandwich better be amazing).  Inedibly hard undercooked potatoes (I really hated these).  Lackluster monte cristo sandwich which I ended up just taking apart and eating in layers.  Haven't been back since.

They definitely cater to "the regulars" and don't seem interested in attracting new business.  They better take heed.  Karsh's next door closed for a reason...

I'll stick with braving the parking lot and traffic for Miracle Mile.  It's much easier to zip through their cafeteria line, and their food quality is much higher.
I love this restaurant and have been coming to Scott's Generations since I was a kid. And I love their new location, it's a very cool style.

The New Yorker was amazing!  One of the best "corned beef & pastrami" sandwiches I've had ever!

The food was so good that we got a dozen bagels to go.

For me, Scott's Generations is the epitome of comfort food. Last week I felt really crummy, and the only think that made me feel better was a piping hot cup of matzoh ball soup and a crispy potato latke with applesauce. 

When I'm feeling right as rain, I indulge with their New Yorker sandwich: corned beef, pastrami and coleslaw on yummy rye bread .... It's amazing. 

Scott's even impressed my New York born-and-raised mother (while Chompie's does not).

Love the old school feel of this deli! You gotta get that this is a family deli not Jimmy johns, you get good food made just how you want in the time it takes to make good food chill and try the nova lox

I live in the neighborhood and have wanted to try this place out for a few years. This morning, my wife, daughter and I walked there for brunch. We sat out side, ordered and ate. The food was average, and a bit overpriced. The place was a little dirty.

I am an Asian American, and was born in Vietnam. My given name is Dung, which is an unfortunate name to have in the states, but it is my given name .  After I paid my tab at the counter , as I walked away, the man who tendered the transaction walked to his colleague with my receipt. They said my name out loud, audible to me from twenty  feet away, and half way out the door, and laughed out loud. He then said,  "hahah, they named their stupid kid Dung!HAHAHAH".   I've lived with this my whole life, but not so much as an adult.   This was disappointing to me that these men, who represent their business, were this rude and insensitive. So, Scott's Generation WILL be receiving a letter of complaint by me and I plan on filing a letter of complaint to the BBB.

If you are looking for a food /  restaurant review, this place is overrated. The food is forgettable  and the service, was beyond description.

We were in the area, and i had heard great things about this place from my boy Nader A so I decided to check it out. I only got a few latkes, some pickles and a kinish but it was all very good. The place is a great little deli with great service and awesome food. The latkes were very good, as were the pickles. I didn't try the kinish, my wife daid it was good though. I need to go back and try some of the pastrami and other goodies. Great little place.

Tried The New Yorker sandwich. It was awesome, you have to try one of these. Even better than at Miracle Mile, which I love. It has so much meat I only ate half the sandwich and all of my fries. Took the other half home for later.
Been going here for 20 years it seems like, and always been good to me. Food is good and I really like the new coffee cafe that opened up inside that place!

We had breakfast there this morning.  "Meh"

Pro's
1.  Very attractive new location.  Well laid out, very nice facility.
2.  Service was very good.  Much better than my experience when they were at 7th Street and Missouri
3.  Their breakfast potatoes are very good.  As was their take on Huevo's Rancheros.  
4.  They had good coffee.

Cons
1.  Relatively expensive for what you get.  They nickel and dime you for everything.  Denny's at 7th street and Camelback has better food and is cheaper.
2.  Orange juice was awful (and my wife loves orange juice).  It tasted like the cheapest stuff they could buy. 
3.  Bagels were stale (yes, the Bagels at a New York deli weren't very good). 

Final judgement: We won't be back.  There are better places out there for breakfast.

I had breakfast there this morning.  The food was good, but the coffee could use improvement (I like good coffee with breakfast and it is high on my list of things I look for in a place to eat breakfast).

Service could use a lot of improvement.  Initially it was ok, but I waited 15 minutes for someone to refill my coffee while my coffee cup sat on the edge of the table.  Meanwhile a waitress and manager walked back a forth a number of times.  I was tired of waiting and went to the counter to leave.  They asked for my check and I said I didn't have it and had been waiting the last 15 minutes without even seeing my waitress.  He found her and said she'd been working a big party in the other room.  I asked why they didn't have the waitress in this room cover?   Waited another 5 minutes at the register for them to get my ticket.  Then a big guy came and asked if he could help.  I told him I had been trying to pay my check.  He got the check from the waitress and said to her "What's wrong with you?".

Bottom line - If they improve their coffee and get their act together on waiting on tables, this could be a very good place.  Otherwise, it won't do well.  

I won't be back.
I have here twice so far. Authentic New York deli offerings. Excellent breakfast and the BEST pickles!  My new favorite local spot!

Ate here kind of randomly on New Year's Day, and it was pretty great!  I was looking for a hangover solution and the food here really hit the spot.  Great selection of breakfast items and friendly service.  The southern scramble that I had was delish.  The coffee flowed as readily as the wine had on the previous evening, so I walked out of Scott's ready to face the new year (right after the nap that I planned).  Also, sitting outside was some of the most interesting people watching I had experienced in years.

I had lunch here with Rand H ,Norm R and Robyn N a small UYE. This was my first trip to Scotts Generations and i found it to be an authentic Jewish deli. I had a bowl (more like a pot) of kreplach soup and a corned beef sandwich that came with pickle spears and coleslaw. The lunch was very good and the soup was amazing. I would and will return to Scotts.

I had breakfast there on a routine Tuesday morning while in the area. I wont be going back. The menu looked good and the place is clean and minimally decorated, but pleasant. 

I ordered the Eggs Benedict and it came with potatoes. My food came out in a timely manner but what a disappointment.  First, it didn't look appetizing at all. The Hollandaise sauce was ill-colored and lacked taste. I compared it to something that may have come from a can or bottle. The poached eggs were fine but they aren't the star of this show - the drab Hollandaise killed the dish as i struggled, to no avail, to find something redeeming about the plate in front of me. The bread served was English Muffin like - but was stale and wasn't browned enough to provide that contrast "crunch" in texture you like in a good Eggs Benedict. The ham was good and seemed to be the most edible component  to me. And the kicker was this, on the bread beneath my bland sauce and poached egg was an unmelted slice of American cheese. I swear to you it looked and tasted exactly like a Kraft single peeled away from its gawd-awful plastic wrapping only moments before and they didn't even bother to melt the processed square of yuck to help disguise it? The potatoes accompanying my dish were pleasant looking but again lacked good taste and were underdone. 

Because I really wanted to find something i liked about the place and to quickly supplant the memory (and taste)  of my breakfast, I ordered an Apple Danish. After a few minutes in the microwave, i was presented with a very hot, and largely mediocre Danish. The pastry parts were dry and dense and lacked life and taste. It was reminiscent of the prepackaged Danish i might find at Costco.  The filling was Apple and sugar so it met the criteria to be called "filling", but nothing more. The glaze was paltry and would have made the pastry/bread part more edible but it was barely noticeable. Again with the corner cutting. 

The service was good and attentive, but it's not her fault my food was so lacking. It just feels like my whole meal was totally cheaped out. Very cheap, poor ingredients and a kitchen that didn't care about how my food tasted and that equals a dissatisfied eater who won't be coming back. You wanna buy and deliver substandard food?  Fine. But then don't charge me 20.00 for breakfast and pretend I won't notice. Charge what Denny's or Waffle House might charge, cause that is the impression your food made on me.
Good New York style deli... Tons of food and worth every minute.. Little dive with big flavor..

I like the servers at my local NY delicatessen to be like they are at Scott's Generations:

* Surly 60 years old ladies
* Low on convo
* High on service
* Standard WTF look accompanied with an occasional  "I'm not amused" look.

I came here for breakfast again the other day and it was hopping with singles, retirees and families.  You walk in and seat yourself. The place is your typical strip mall storefront that stretches back lengthwise with a next door addition. On one side you'll find a series of naughahyde booths and on the other side you'll find the cash register, kitchen, deli counter where you can order fat free bialys, Hanukkah cookies, gefilte fish, latkes or side salads and luncheon meats by the pound. 

Breakfast here is dirt cheap. The breakfast sandwich is $4.  Eggs, hamsteak, home fries (sauteed with seasoning and grilled onions) and a bagel is $5 something.  Surly little old lady servers take your order and shout it into the kitchen - all old school and stuff.  Once my friend (who dislikes bell peppers) ordered the corned beef hash skillet and was disappointed to see bell peppers in the hash. We told the server and she brought out an entirely new dish, with new eggs and home fries.  No sigh. No face. No questions asked. 

Lunch and dinner looks pretty good - an extensive selection of sandwiches and traditional deli favorites.  Haven't had it though.  I can't seem to make it there by the geriatric last dinner time of 5 pm and 8 pm throughout the week (!)

Food here is probably 3.5 stars.  Service here is a solid 4 stars.
This place is a solid deli in the valley. They used to be a lot more restaurants like this but they have seem to disappear. This one is rocksolid. All your favorites are represented and delicious.

I love going to Scott's for breakfast. Very casual, seat yourself. The staff is very friendly and it seems everyone has worked there for ages - maybe family. Try the LEO (lox, eggs, onions) special. 

Their sandwiches are huge. Seriously, I'm not sure how one gets his or her entire mouth around a bite. And, being from the northeast and a member of the tribe myself, I love the feeling of an authentic Jewish deli.

These 4 stars are based on the tasty food at Scott's. I enjoyed the latkes, 3 huge potato cakes served with applesauce and sour cream. Hubby ordered ham steak and eggs, accompanied by a side of home fries and almost cleaned his plate (ham steak was huge!). The booths were large and cozy; decor was very home diner style comfortable. Unfortunately the service was so so. Our food arrived fast but our waitress looked annoyed at having to serve us. We showed up at 3:20 Sunday when they close at 4:00, so maybe we arrived to close to day's end?  We will visit again soon and see how it goes because the latkes are already calling me back....

New location, clean and elegant, very nice waiters and excellent food! We had Pastrami Reuben, smoked salmon w/salad, potato pancakes, hot dogs and a knish. Everything was delicious, and at a reasonable price. A great experience! We definitely recommend!

I had been waiting to go to Scott's Generations for about a month. After reading the reviews the build up for me was worth the wait.
I had the Reuben  Reuben with piled high corn beef. The rye bread was grilled to perfection. The sandwich comes with cold slaw (sweet and tangy) and french fries that reminded me of the kind that were made at Nathan's from New York.
My brother had the James Cagney sandwich. It consists of Brisket of beef, melted swiss cheese, grilled onions, lettuce &
tomatoes served on toasted garlic onion roll. 
We are ex New Yorkers who both agree. Scott's is hands down  the best deli on the west coast. 
We both can't wait to go back again and again to try other menu items.
if i have errands in the neighborhood i always stop at scott's. a rueben or new yorker always makes me happy. since they expanded the dining room it is much easier to score a table, too.

WOW! Fantastic place that I have been ignoring for years, but glad I finally came to  my senses! 

So its hard to order here because everything looks so darn good, literally I could not make up my mind on what to get, I wanted it ALL!  So I settled for the corned beef hash and it was FRESH MADE AND FANTASTIC!!!! The sandwiches all looked piled high and the pancakes are huge! 

The waiter was super knowledgable, friendly, caring (when do ever hear that one in a review?), and seemed to love his job to the fullest.

Do yourself a favor and stop in, this is as good as it gets!

Service, cleanliness, quality, price, and taste are all beyond 5 stars. Being from New York you expect a great deal from Delis and food that totes a back east flare. Whether you're homesick or hungry, you will get your life at this place all the way around. You'll beg to pay double your receipt. Go at the time of reading this post for your own good!

Ehhhhh 

Thats really all I have to say about this place. I randomly stopped here for my lunch break while I was working in the area. I'm originally from NY and really REALLY miss the NY style deli/diner's. 
I was excited to see if they carried cannolis, unfortunately they didn't, they might but that day didn't have any. Was really hoping to buy 2 for my parents, whom are natives to the Bronx. 

I sat myself, the tables were a bit dirty. Service was a older woman, she was very pleasant. I got a grilled chicken sandich and fries. The sandwich was great, fries were burnt and horrible. 

I MIGHT, just might stop by here again, if I'm in the area and have no other options.

Scotts Generations is tucked back in an unassuming shopping center. The staff was friendly and attentive. We came for lunch and decided on the Ruben and the Cheese Steak sandwiches. They were super delish, hot and fresh. Not to mention the portions were huge. Each came with allot of fried and quartered potatoes on the side and neither of us could finish, so ,ended up taking more then an extra meal home with us. Behind the counter they had beagles, sides, smoked fish and more to choose from, which a steady stream of people kept coming in for things to order. Service is a definite plus as everyone I saw was being served promptly. It has an old and tired decor but the food and service more then make up for this.

One of my favorite sandwhich shops EVER. OMG yum come in with an appetite, empty stomach, and loose clothing bc the portions are incredible. Reminds me of back east. Be starving you leave satisfied.  The cooks in the back are amazing and are always curteous!  Try the Philly.  My favorite is Scotts rueben.

First thought upon seeing my Scotts special Reuben reuben...damn, wish I had a second stomach. 

I tried Scotts for lunch. The place was kind of cramped and about half full. Theres tons of deli meats on the left ready to be cut and several booths to sit in. I sat in the back where the tv was on. I regretted sitting back there as its next to the waitress' lounge table against the wall where they gossiped about their day. Nothing wrong with that but I wish I'd sat more in the front. The place was so-so. The staff could have piped down and grabbed a broom and swept the place up a bit. Or maybe they could have grabbed some clean rags and gave the menus a good sponge bath. I seriously wish I brought some hand sanitizer after looking thru that thing. 

Anyhow, I didn't come for the ambiance as its a deli. My food came out within 5 or 10 minutes and the sandwich was freakin HUGE. Two massive pieces of reuben stacked with meat, bread, and sauerkraut. It was surrounded by short fat krinkle cut fries and a shot glass size of cole slaw. 

The first 3 bites of my king kong Reuben were absolutely delicious.  I thought to myself, this is what I'm talking about.  The bread was outstanding. Lightly buttered and crisp. The meat was tasty as well and steaming hot. The sauerkraut didn't do much for me nor did the cole slaw but I'm not really a fan of either. The biggest disappointment was the fries were undercooked. Nothing worst than hard undercooked  fries. 

There was so much food I had to ask for a to go box. I ride a motorcycle so I usually never take left overs as I have to strap down the box on my passenger seat and it looks a bit ridiculous. However, after dropping 15+ on a sandwich for lunch and considering how delicious the sandwich was I just didn't have it in me to leave it behind. 

Scotts was probably a 3.5 for me overall. It would have been teetering on a 4 but the fries and cleanliness dropped it down for me.  I would certainly be open to give it another try and maybe take a friend to share with next time as no one should ever attempt to eat that much food unless they are going into hibernation soon.

I would had given them six stars if possible. WOW... what a sandwich. I had the "Reuben- Reuben" packed with corned beef. Totally worth every penny. Served with a mountain of fried potato too. We sat in the dog friendly patio on a perfect Phoenix day.

I just found another reason to go to Phoenix. I only wish we had a Deli closer to Monterey then Phoenix that served a Corned Beef/ Pastrami sandwich as good as Scott's Generation Restaurant. I had the "Reuben-Reuben" that was by far best sandwich I've ever had. Stacked tall with a combination of Corned Beef/ Pastrami, Swiss cheese, Sauerkraut, grilled to perfection. It was so big the waitress asked if I wanted a box to take the rest home. I said it was so good that I was going to try to eat it all. Now I don't have to eat dinner. Reasonably priced too.
Food was okay. Service was very slow. Waitress must have been on break. She returned smelling like an ash tray.
Great new place. Hearty, quality, affordable food.  This is the breakfast place I've been waiting for in this neighborhood. The sandwiches look pretty darn good as well.

Definitely going to be my new favorite NY style restaurant to get some great tasting food and enjoy some really yummy take out products as well. Who doesn't like a tasty deli that serves Breakfast all day long and has Giant Sandwiches as well as all the traditional standards everyone loves.

This is their new location since the last one closed and it is very clean and comfortable inside. The menu is HUGE and has everything you could possibly imagine. They even have several items that you can bring home as well as fresh Bagels, Deli Meats, smoked Fish, and then some.

Ordered the New Yorker which has Corned Beef & Pastrami, cole slaw & Russian dressing piled high on your favorite bread and served with fries & pickles. It was very good and more food than you should probably be eating without a good walk afterwards.

My wife mistakenly ordered the Denver in Phoenix Egg Skillet which has diced ham, onions, tomatoes, green peppers topped with melted swiss & cheddar cheeses with a side of fries. She was really wanting an Omelet and distinctly asked for one. We were surprised when it came to the table and notice that is was not an omelet. We were both so hungry that we decided not to mention anything at the time.

When the server came back I made the comment that my wife's dish looked more like a skillet and not an omelet. She mentioned that it was not an omelet and wanted to know if they could remake the order. At that point half the food was already eaten so the manager kindly offered to remove the charge for that dish from the bill. Nice!

Overall service was friendly and a little sparse. Then again it was a busy Sunday and the place was rocking with hungry customers. We were both surprised at their dedication to keep us happy and a future returning customer. Not all places go to that extent and it makes a big difference.

Bring the family and anyone hungry for some delicious gut busting portions of food. They even have a larger room in the back for bigger groups of people. I'm personally hooked on their Pastrami and will be stopping by here on the way home for some take out as well. OH YEAH BABY!

4.25 STARS

Owner yelling at employees in front of customers!

We ended up leaving and not ordering anything because we were having a nice Sunday and didn't feel like we should have to endure the thick air of negitivity. The owner was complaining loudly to a number of other employees about something. Then a young man/employee came in and he started yelling at him. Honestly, all this yelling, cursing, shaming, digust went on for over 8minutes! I couldn't belive that any establishment owner could be that ignorant. 

And to the young man being berated in front of everyone within a 20ft radius, RUN!!! I don't care what you did or didn't do, you don't deserve to be treated that way! 

Note to owner - If you need to repremand an employee, you need to do it behind closed doors. Furthermore, there is no need to complain to everyone that will listen, or HAS to listen prior to even speaking with him! 

Bad, bad, bad. I would never try this place. It was dirty as well.

Bagels, lox, and cream cheese has been our family's traditional Christmas morning breakfast for over 50 years.  We began ordering from Scott's after MULTIPLE issues/problems with another New York style deli restaurant in town.  Since then, our breakfasts have not only been completely stress free, but delicious as well!  Scott's does a great job and we couldn't be more pleased to be taking our business to him from now on!

Went for breakfast this weekend, and was aghast that I've lived two miles from  Jewish deli I was unaware of...

The atmosphere is great, and the food was good too. It's all pretty heavy and not especially healthy, but great options for a variety of eaters...unless you're a vegan, but I'm not going there.

I'd definitely go back, if not for the world's most amazing food, but for the feeling you get in a Jewish deli :) I'm also hoping to try pastries on a day where I don't consume several pounds of food...

We saw this place feature on a TV show, they featured the Corn Beef Hash as one of the best, so for breakfast I ordered Eggs and Hash, it was very good, crispy and moist at the same time, not too salty or greasy like hash can sometimes be. My husband had the Eggs Benedict and he loved it. The place is in a strip mall, and not very fancy. Waitress was very prompt  and friendly. I would probably go back and try lunch next time, before I could really say if it would be worth a third try.

im not sure if this update is kosher but fuck it. i update for three reasons. 

1. brother just got back from visiting the mom in phoenix.  he went there with said mother based on my rec and loved it. his vivid descriptions of his pastrami, corned beef and chopped liver sandwich have been torturing me nightly since his return. 

2. no jewish deli in portland can touch this deli. memories of scotts + sad reality of portland deli scene= 5+ star upgrade.

3. i'm quite sure the only reason i gave it four instead of five stars initially was because of the lame name. that was rude of me. yeah, so, it does have a lame ass name. maybe only 4 jewish mothers in the 80s named their kids scott- it's a pretty goyshe name and i dont get it. but judging on the name was shallow and superficial of me.

already looking into best practices regarding chopped liver delivery methods.

great food.. love breakfast at Scott's Generation. Recently is has changed a bit, I think it is a staff change which has not helped the restaurants atmosphere. But don't let that stop you, order an full breakfast you will be stuff and happy! Their bagels are great, cream cheeses are fantastic, love the pickles, and American fry's. give it a try, I think you'll love it.

Pastrami, pastrami, pastrami, pastrami, pastrami, pastrami." on rye...that's the way I judge a dood Deli, by their Pastrami Sandwhich. Well this isn't up there with Chompies (portin wise) but it sure was close. The pastrami sandwich was surprisingly good. I prefer thick, hand-carved pastrami, "The pastrami was a perfect mix of lean and fatty portions and  and freshly carved. Definitely better than your ordinary pastrami. The pastrami here is to die for. Never in my life I imagined that pastrami, or any kind of meat for that matter, can be so succulent and juicy. It literally melts in your mouth. 

I got their Pastrami Sandwhich, my wife got their reuben. To go we got 6 bagels, lox spread, chopped liver, herring in sour cream sauce and some pickels.  

What's good here, the answer is everything As for the desserts ... The massive slabs of Cheeese Cake was moist and ridiculously good (and ridiculously big)

FOOD:  Unbelievably lean and tasty. I thoroughly enjoyed every bite of my sandwich. oh and their pickles..... don't even get me STARTED they were  exactly how grandma used to make them and the pickles just topped it off. PRICE: Although the prices are a bit high you will definitely have leftovers for lunch the next day. CONCLUSION:  The portions sizes are very generous,  especially for the price! I highly recommend giving this place a try!

Definitely the best corn beef hash in town. The corn beef is grilled mixed with peppers and onions with two eggs on top, side of H Ground and Choice of bread (do the bagels).   At $11 it's a great deal!!

I wish I had time to try more of their food.....

Chopped liver bagel is great, and i love their pickles. 

Friendly staff, fast service. lots of room.
Excellent food! You have to come here and try this place...you can't go wrong with anything on the menu!!  Seriously you gotta try it

The corned beef hash is always really good and they sell lunch meat by the pound I mean good lunch meat by the pound the chicken noodle soup is so good and all the waiters and waitresses are great a definite must go

This place is the worst.  Terrible service.  You have to battle to get peoples' attention even to be given a table.  Then they never come by to refill coffee.  Horrible food. My wife ordered an omelette and it came with slices of American cheese on top.  Looked and tasted disgusting.  It's a shame there isn't a Chompie's or Goldman's nearby.

While searching for a place open for New Year's Day during the late morning/early afternoon, we discovered that Scott's Generations was serving people still and decided to stop by.  A couple other times we have tried to go it has unfortunately been closed, but lucked out yesterday.

The location is a little hidden in the corner and unless you were looking for it, probably would just drive on by.  I ordered breakfast and my friend had a sandwich.  The mix of people in the establishment varied a lot in age group and the decor is quite eclectic.  I have been in search for a good Jewish deli place since I have left Chicago and have yet to find one to replace my favorite still back at home, but for now, this will suffice.

The portions of my corned beef hash were very generous, but the eggs were a little overdone.  My friend's club sandwich on sourdough was gigantic and was served with a decent sized pickle and plenty of home fries.  The fries themselves were a little bland and could've used seasoning, but I suppose that's what the salt, pepper, and/or ketchup on the table is for.  The sandwich itself he said was good, but nothing special.  

I will have to go back and try some of their other fare, but have tried the soups and corned beef in the past.  The soups are okay - I've tried the matzo ball and kreplach.  The stock could use a bit more depth instead of mere salt, but the corned beef is delicious.  I have also picked up bagels and the nova lox is quite yummy.  

If you're in search for a place with standard Jewish deli fare, this may be the best you're going to find around here (at least from what I've read), but honestly I still miss the places in Chicago or New York a lot!

Terrible service and long wait times cannot  make up for decent food.  My dad loved the old place and we were excited to see it move to a clean updated location. We've been twice and both times service and wait time for food was over 40 minutes. I will not go back.

I think this can give the Jewish delis of NYC a run for their money. The place itself is clean and spacious, and the comfortable booths were just right for the mini-UYE with Rand H., Mike C., and Robyn N. I ordered a half pastrami sandwich and a bowl of kreplach soup; these came with sides of coleslaw and pickle spears. A plate of bagel chips was also served with the soup. The pastrami sandwich was superb and overstuffed like it should be; really tasty - I thought I should have ordered a whole sandwich instead of a half. The kreplach was good; tasty and hearty, and a bowl could have been a meal. I really have to come back here to try other stuff, such as belly lox ... but return visits won't be too frequent for me, only because the food is quite pricey. The half sandwich, bowl of soup, and coffee cost close to 15 bucks.

Original review: 24AUG2010:
Love Scott's!!! Just had the corned beef hash after my root canal...Still enjoyed it chewing on the left side...Been coming to Scott's for years!!!  Never leave hungry!!! From breakfast to lunch, the soups are fabulous and the sandwiches you can feed 2-3 people!!!

The Monte Cristo Sandwich is the way to go when you order here. It's huge! So be sure to have an appetite or bring a friend to share. This deli style restaurant is laid back and casual. I feel like I'm eating in a deli in the heart of New York City. I have fond memories of dining with my mom here. The service is easy and quick and the food is delicious!
Place is quiet at 6.00 am . Need updating , seats are weathered.the potions are large . Food is decent , service ice is a little  slow . Location is convenient

Scott's Generations? Never again. I've been wanting to try Scott's for years. I love deli, and I was very disappointed by the food, service and overall experience I had at Scott's today. 

During the end of the lunch rush Scott's was empty. That should have been a sign. The restaurant was filthy. The temperature was hot and sticky despite having the the door open (it was about 72 in phoenix today.)

The booths had exposed cushioning, tables hadn't been cleared or cleaned and the floor looked like something that belonged in an episode of kitchen nightmares. Ignoring these details was a poor choice on my part. 

My friend and I finally found a clean-ish booth and sat down. Our table was dirty, and when the waitress came by I had to ask her to wipe it off even though there were visible crumbs and our menus were sticky. She acted like it had never occurred to her to clean a table off before. She actually tilted her head when I asked her to do so, as if she had been confused by the request. We should have just left. 

We ordered our food. I got a pathetic bowl of matzo ball soup, my friend a sad looking chicken noodle. I had one very tiny measly looking matzo ball, and the veggies had been cooked to death. There were chicken bones in my soup. The flavor tasted like it had been seasoned with a generic version of Stouffer's dressing mix. 

I ordered a lean pastrami and asked for it to go. It came to our table without fries  accompanied by the saddest, wilted coleslaw. It was not prepared to go. The pastrami was fatty (despite the menu bragging about how they don't charge extra for lean) The pickles were great, and house made. The pickles were the only bright spot of the meal. 

My friend asked if they had soda by the bottle, the waitress forgot that they carried Dr Brown's (a deli staple) and I had to jog her memory. She forgot the request twice and after being reminded twice she finally brought the soda.

By this point I was so over it I just wanted to leave. I asked for a box, she over charged us, I didn't give a flying fig about that and over paid just to be able to leave. 

Six hours later my stomach is upset. I won't be returning. I may be calling the health inspector. Like many generational things, I hope Scott's gets left in the past.

We have eaten here several times and always happy with the food and service. The last time we went everything was off, very dry meat which has never happened before. SO this will not keep me away as it must have been an off day.

I am giving an extra point for kind service and a generally clean and pleasing environment. That said, the place may need a new cook or new recipes. The food is pretty bad. We ordered a tuna melt that was swimming in mayo with overly hard, grilled rye bread. It was just a nasty sandwich. And their coleslaw was the same - swimming in mayo. What's the deal with the mayo? I had their food earlier and the experience was the same. The restaurant was not that busy. The woman at the front were very nice and attentive, but they can't overcome pretty bad food.  Maybe we've ordered the wrong menu items, but this was our experience....

Living in Midtown Phoenix we have a lot of trendy breakfast stops that offer top notch meals, but with those top notch meals comes higher prices and long waits. Some days you just want cheap eggs and pancakes without a ton of effort. Scott's Generations is my go to for these days. I love walking in and automatically getting the feeling that you're in a mom and pop diner straight out of a Seinfeld episode (they sell black and white cookies!) The service is always friendly and fast. The food's not the best in town, but sometimes basic pancakes and eggs is all you want and they do it well. But don't expect to have fancy pancakes with lots of add ins like other nearby pancake places. So if a basic breakfast or lunch is what you're looking for, I would definitely come here.

Recently ate lunch at Scott's and being from the NY/NJ metro area, I know good deli and I can honestly say Scotts can give any deli in NY & NJ a run for their money! The pastrami and corned beef sandwich with chopped liver was mouthwatering and the fries were divine! Our server was attentive and knowledgeable. Sadly didn't have enough room for dessert but will be saving room the next time I go back! They have a nice outdoor space and a large dining room. Can't wait to go back and indulge in more and feel like I'm back east!

The Fantastic Mr. It's Complicated and I went here for lunch today, and as we'd experienced separately in the past - the food was great!

Based on the foods he's disgusted by, I didn't order what I was in the mood for - had he seen it, he may not have been able to eat at all. So I went with the New Yorker (corned beef, pastrami, slaw and Russian dressing) on rye with the slaw on the side. He had the Black Forest (turkey, corned beef, grilled onions and Swiss.)
Both are served with pickles (I believe house-made) and fries. The bread is great, the meat quality is great - and as we both packed half a sandwich and most of the fries into boxes for another meal, we were reminded that maybe next time we should just share a sandwich.

Like all good delis - the portions are HUGE. And like all good Jewish delis - the service is subpar, the decor is hopelessly dated, the prices are definitely fair for the quality and quantity, and something about it just feels like "home."

I made a mistake though. I ordered coffee instead of a chocolate egg cream. Too few places make a decent egg cream  - and I missed my opportunity. Then again, that's a good excuse to have to go back soon! (As if I needed one!)

Holy cow! The Scott's Perfect Reuben-Reuben Sandwich is an accurate portrayal of perfection! I got it with corned beef and pastrami, with sauerkraut and Swiss cheese, grilled excellently on rye bread. 

This is the perfect place in Phoenix to grab a quick bite while you are doing some grocery shopping (or clothing shopping at the Buffalo Exchange a few stores down) and the price is very reasonable here. It came with fries, cole slaw and wedged pickles.

It definitely reminded me of what you'd find at Kat's Deli and Second Ave Deli in NYC!

Oy! A real New York deli restaurant in Phoenix! We came in for breakfast on recommendation from my sister and will definitely make this our go to place when in town. I had the Monte Cristo sandwich, huge, full of all the goodies, turkey, ham, cheese, heaven between two slices of thick bread! Right brain had a simple egg breakfast, bagels, yes, BAGELS! We all had something different but brought food home -portions HUGE. Anything your heart desires in kosher is on the menu, again heavenly!
Come, satisfy your deli need, be full, be happy! Repeat as needed!

My family and I went here on a Sunday for the first time and expecting the food to be delicious. Well obviously when I arrived you were seated promptly and ordered our food. I ordered the matzo ball soup and it was totally disgusting and incorrectly made. It was tasteless, small and dry so I decided to order the borscht and unfortunately guess what it comes out of a glass jar from the supermarket with hardly any beats in it, just beat liquid, what a waste. For the main course I ordered the smoke platter which consisted of nova lox, smoked fish and sturgeon.
The nova lox was dry was not oily sturgeon was dried out I have to say I was pretty disappointed with this location and I had better. Goldman's Delicatessen is much better and no not Chompies that place is a rip-off. JJ's Delicatessen along with New York Bagel & Bialy those places are much better.

If there was no other reason to go to Scott's, go for there bialy's and the take home.  I still have no idea what a real jewish deli should be but this has got to be close to it from what I've seen of it over the years. (Need to go to New York and try a few there to find out, I guess.)  Go early for the bialy's. or ask them to hold some for you.  They run out fast.  This place grows on you.
Great spot for breakfast and lunch.  Large portions, so be hungry, split or take some home. New location is great.

This place is a favorite among my boyfriend's family and it's definitely become a favorite of mine. We try to make it a point to go here for breakfast at least once a month. Their bagels are the best in Phoenix! They put the toppings not only on the top, but on the bottom of the bagel, so no matter what side you eat, you're getting topping goodness. The service can be slow, but it always ends up being worth it.

Came here cause of the Entertainment Book coupon, they no longer take it. Regardless we enjoyed the New Yorker, and hot pastrami sandwiches on rye. Both were huge and tasty, cole slaw very good french fries excellent and pickles delicious. Check out my sandwich and the large half of each sandwich which we had for dinner. My opinion they are bettrr than Chompies.

So far I have been here about 3-5 time within the last 6 months. And I have to say I keep coming back because the food is amazing and the staff are great. They have a large menus of sorts I seem to stay in the breakfast area. But I have brought many people on over here to try a great place for food and experience.

My part Jewish friend has been raving about this deli so come payday we went to check it out. Ive been in Phoenix a little over a month and have been getting sick from the food here...diarrhea lots, shit my pants once... anyway, i like to eat in divey non-american cuisine. This place aint seedy enough for me, I suppose.

I did not get ill from the food here

However....

 $12.95 for a sandwich, fries, and a dollop of soggy coleslaw ???

I kept hearing from my friend, his mom and the waitress that the sandys are HUGE.
nope.

Thought we might split one.
nope.

My sandwich was flavorless..err..thats a lie.. it tasted like stale bread.

$29.98 for 2 sandwiches and 2 sodas (its an effin sandwich!!!). I only had $40 (only ?)

Left the waitress $5.

Gave my friend the other $5 to put toward a plane ticket to New York where he might experience Kosher (and a bit of his heritage) on a more realistic scale.

..the fries were good tho.
